title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§® Why is 0! = 1?
text:
1.1 ğŸ§  Form 1: Combinatorial Interpretation
The factorial \(n!\) represents the number of ways to arrange \(n\) distinct elements.

For \(n = 3\): \(3! = 6\) permutations
For \(n = 2\): \(2! = 2\) permutations
For \(n = 1\): \(1! = 1\) permutation
For \(n = 0\): How many permutations of the empty set?

Answer: \[
\boxed{1 \text{ permutation (the empty set itself)}}
\] \[
\Rightarrow \boxed{0! = 1}
\]


1.1.1 ğŸŒ³ Illustration: Combinatorial Interpretation


The factorial \(n!\) represents the number of permutations of \(n\) elements.
Example: permutations of \(\{a, b\}\)
\[
\begin{aligned}
2! &= 2: \{a,b\}, \{b,a\} \\\\
1! &= 1: \{a\} \\\\
0! &= 1: \{\,\} \text{ (empty set)}
\end{aligned}
\]






Visual representation of permutations



Conclusion: There are exactly \(\boxed{1}\) ways to arrange zero elements.
\[
\boxed{0! = 1}
\]

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§® Why is 0! = 1?
text:
1.2 ğŸ” Form 2: Recursive Definition
The factorial function is defined recursively:
\[
n! = n \cdot (n - 1)!, \quad \text{with } 1! = 1
\]
Applying the definition for \(n = 1\):
\[
1! = 1 \cdot 0! \Rightarrow 1 = 1 \cdot 0! \Rightarrow \boxed{0! = 1}
\]
This definition is essential for the factorial function to be valid from \(n = 1\) onward.


1.2.1 ğŸŒ³ Illustration: Recursive Definition







\(3! = 3 \cdot 2!\)
\(2! = 2 \cdot 1!\)
\(1! = 1 \cdot 0! \Rightarrow 0! = 1\)


\(\boxed{0! = 1}\) is necessary so that the recursion â€œterminatesâ€ correctly.

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§® Why is 0! = 1?
text:
1.3 ğŸ”¢ Form 3: Binomial Coefficient
Use the binomial coefficient formula:
\[
\binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}
\]
Special case:
\[
\binom{0}{0} = \frac{0!}{0! \cdot 0!}
\Rightarrow 1 = \frac{0!}{(0!)^2}
\Rightarrow (0!)^2 = 0!
\] \[
\Rightarrow \boxed{0! = 1}
\]
This ensures that combinatorial formulas remain valid for \(n = 0\).


1.3.1 ğŸ§© Illustration: Binomial Coefficient





There is exactly one way to choose 0 elements from the empty set.

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§® Why is 0! = 1?
text:
1.4 ğŸ§¬ Form 4: Gamma Function
The Gamma function generalizes the factorial to real and complex numbers:
\[
\Gamma(n) = \int_0^{\infty} x^{n-1} e^{-x} \, dx, \quad \text{for } n > 0
\]
It satisfies the relation:
\[
\Gamma(n+1) = n! \quad \text{when } n \in \mathbb{N}
\]
Therefore:
\[
0! = \Gamma(1) = \int_0^{\infty} e^{-x} \, dx = \left[ -e^{-x} \right]_0^{\infty} =
\] \[
= 0 - (-1) = 1
\]

Thus, the definition \(0! = 1\) is consistent with the Gamma function.



1.4.1 ğŸ§  Proof that \(\Gamma(n+1) = n!\)
1. Definition of the Gamma function:
\[
\Gamma(x) = \int_0^{\infty} t^{x-1} e^{-t} \, dt
\]
2. Fundamental property:
\[
\Gamma(x+1) = x \cdot \Gamma(x)
\]
3. Base case: \(\Gamma(1) = \int_0^{\infty} e^{-t} \, dt = 1 = 0!\)
4. Inductive step: Assume \(\Gamma(k+1) = k!\). Then:
\[
\Gamma(k+2) = (k+1) \cdot \Gamma(k+1) =
\] \[
= (k+1) \cdot k! = (k+1)!
\]

Conclusion:
\[
\boxed{\Gamma(n+1) = n! \quad \text{for all } n \in \mathbb{N}}
\]



1.4.2 ğŸ“ Proof of the Property \(\Gamma(x+1) = x \cdot \Gamma(x)\)
Goal: Show that
\[
\Gamma(x+1) = x \cdot \Gamma(x)
\]
Definition of the Gamma function:
\[
\Gamma(x+1) = \int_0^{\infty} t^x e^{-t} \, dt
\]
Integration by parts formula:
\[
\int u \, dv = uv - \int v \, du
\]
Applying integration by parts:

Let \(u = t^x \Rightarrow du = x t^{x-1} \, dt\)
Let \(dv = e^{-t} \, dt \Rightarrow v = -e^{-t}\)


Applying the formula:
\[
\Gamma(x+1) = -t^x e^{-t} \Big|_0^\infty + \int_0^{\infty} x t^{x-1} e^{-t} \, dt
\]
Analyzing the boundary term:
\[
\lim_{t \to \infty} t^x e^{-t} = 0, \quad \lim_{t \to 0^+} t^x e^{-t} = 0 \; \text{(for $x > 0$)}
\]
Hence:
\[
-t^x e^{-t} \Big|_0^\infty = 0
\]
Therefore:
\[
\Gamma(x+1) = x \int_0^\infty t^{x-1} e^{-t} \, dt = x \cdot \Gamma(x)
\]


Thus, the relation holds for all \(x > 0\).




1.4.3 ğŸ” Justification of the Limits
To apply integration by parts, we show that:
\[
\lim_{t \to \infty} t^x e^{-t} = 0 \quad \text{and} \quad \lim_{t \to 0^+} t^x e^{-t} = 0 \quad (x > 0)
\]

1. As \(t \to \infty\):
\[
\frac{t^x}{e^t} \to 0
\]
since the exponential dominates any power.
Therefore:
\[
\boxed{\lim_{t \to \infty} t^x e^{-t} = 0}
\]

2. As \(t \to 0^+\):
\[
t^x \to 0, \quad e^{-t} \to 1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad t^x e^{-t} \to 0 \cdot 1 = 0
\]
Therefore:
\[
\boxed{\lim_{t \to 0^+} t^x e^{-t} = 0}
\]


Both limits ensure the boundary term of the integration by parts vanishes.




1.4.4 ğŸ“Š Visualizing the Limits with Graphs





Behavior of \(t^x e^{-t}\) as \(t \to 0^+\) and \(t \to \infty\).



1.4.5 ğŸ“ˆ Graph of the Gamma Function





The plot shows that \(\Gamma(x)\) is continuous and satisfies \(\Gamma(1) = 1\), hence \(0! = 1\).



1.4.6 ğŸ§® Gamma Function â€” Graphic Illustration





The plot highlights that \(\Gamma(1) = 1\), which justifies that \(0! = 1\).

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§® Why is 0! = 1?
section: 1.5 ğŸ§© Form 5: Limit of the Gamma Function
text:
1.5 ğŸ§© Form 5: Limit of the Gamma Function
The Gamma function extends the factorial beyond positive integers. We can define:
\[
0! = \lim_{x \to 0^+} \Gamma(x + 1) = \Gamma(1) = 1
\]
Justification via continuity of the analytic extension of the factorial.

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§® Why is 0! = 1?
section: 1.6 âœ´ï¸ Form 6: Empty Product and Product Definition
text:
1.6 âœ´ï¸ Form 6: Empty Product and Product Definition
The general definition of factorial as a product:
\[
n! = \prod_{k=1}^{n} k
\]
Applying this definition for \(n = 0\):
\[
0! = \prod_{k=1}^{0} k = 1
\]
In algebra, the product over an empty set equals 1, because 1 is the multiplicative identity.

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§® Why is 0! = 1?
text:
1.7 ğŸ”„ Form 7: Permutation \(P(0,0)\)
The general formula for permutations is:
\[
P(n, r) = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!}
\]
Applying with \(n = 0\) and \(r = 0\):
\[
P(0, 0) = \frac{0!}{0!} = 1
\]
For the number of permutations of \(0\) elements to be \(1\), it is necessary that \(0! = 1\).

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§® Why is 0! = 1?
text:
1.8 ğŸ”¢ Form 8: Taylor Series of \(e^x\)
The exponential function has the following Taylor series expansion:
\[
e^x = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{x^n}{n!}
\]
The constant term of the series is:
\[
\frac{1}{0!}
\]
We know that:
\[
e^0 = 1 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \frac{1}{0!} = 1 \quad \Rightarrow \boxed{0! = 1}
\]

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§® Why is 0! = 1?
section: 1.9 ğŸ§® Form 9: Logarithm of the Factorial
text:
1.9 ğŸ§® Form 9: Logarithm of the Factorial
A known identity relates the factorial to logarithms:
\[
\log(n!) = \sum_{k=1}^{n} \log(k)
\]
Applying with \(n = 0\):
\[
\log(0!) = \sum_{k=1}^{0} \log(k) = 0 \quad \Rightarrow \quad \boxed{0! = 1}
\]
The empty sum returns zero, preserving the coherence of the logarithm property.

1.10 ğŸ’» Form 10: Computational Systems
The definition \(0! = 1\) is universally adopted in programming languages and software:

Python: math.factorial(0) returns 1
R: factorial(0) returns 1
Julia: gamma(1) returns 1
Mathematica: Factorial[0] returns 1

All follow the standard mathematical convention:
\[
\boxed{0! = 1}
\]

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§® Why is 0! = 1?
text:
1.11 ğŸ§  Conclusion
Each approach leads us to the same result:
\[
\boxed{0! = 1}
\]
This equality is consistent with:

combinatorial logic,
the recursive definition,
algebraic binomial formulas,
the Gamma function generalization,
continuity of the Gamma function,
the empty product definition,
coherence with permutations \(P(n,n)\),
validity of the Taylor series of \(e^x\),
the logarithm definition of the factorial,
and computational implementation.


A well-chosen definition is a bridge between ideas.

NoteğŸ“– Definitions



Let a rational function \(f(x)=\dfrac{p(x)}{q(x)}\).

We say that \(x=a\) is a vertical asymptote if:

Horizontal asymptote:
We say that \(y=L\) is a horizontal asymptote if \[

x=\frac{-3\pm\sqrt{25}}{2\cdot2}=\frac{-3\pm5}{4}\;\Rightarrow\;x_1=-2,\;x_2=\tfrac12.
\] With \(a=2>0\), the parabola is concave upwards; so \(f(x)\ge 0\) outside the interval between the roots (and includes the roots because it is \(\geqslant\)): \[
x\in(-\infty,-2]\cup\left[\tfrac12,\infty\right).
\] Solution: \((-\infty,-2]\cup[0.5,\infty)\).












NoteExercise 5 â€” Operations with intervals



Let \(A=(-\infty,4)\) and \(B=[1,7)\).
(a) \(A\cap B\) (b) \(A\cup B\)






NoteStep-by-step solution






\(A\cap B\): points that are in both.
\(A\) goes up to \(4\) (open), \(B\) starts at \(1\) (closed) and goes up to \(7\) (open).
Intersection: from \(1\) to \(4\), including \(1\) and excluding \(4\): \([1,4)\).
\(A\cup B\): points that are in at least one.
The union covers from \(-\infty\) up to \(7\) open (since \(B\) already covers \([1,7)\) and \(A\) covers \((-\infty,4)\)): \((-\infty,7)\).

Answers: (a) \([1,4)\) (b) \((-\infty,7)\).












NoteExercise 6 â€” Solve the inequalities below.




Product: \(x(x-1)>0\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





Roots at \(x=0\) and \(x=1\). Since the leading coefficient is \(+1\), the product is positive outside the interval between the roots.
âœ… Solution: \((-\infty,0)\cup(1,\infty)\).





Product: \((x-1)(x+2)<0\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





Roots at \(x=-2\) and \(x=1\). Leading coefficient \(+1\) â‡’ negative between the roots.
âœ… Solution: \((-2,1)\).





Quadratic: \(x^2+4x-21>0\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





\(\Delta=4^2-4\cdot1\cdot(-21)=100\).
Roots: \(x=\tfrac{-4\pm10}{2}\Rightarrow x=-7,\,3\).
Parabola opens upwards â‡’ \(>0\) outside.
âœ… Solution: \((-\infty,-7)\cup(3,\infty)\).





Quadratic: \(2x^2+x<3\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





\(2x^2+x-3<0\).
\(\Delta=1+24=25\).
Roots: \(x=\tfrac{-1\pm5}{4}\Rightarrow x=-\tfrac32,\,1\).
\(<0\) between the roots.
âœ… Solution: \(\left(-\tfrac32,\,1\right)\).





Quadratic: \(4x^2+10x-6<0\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





\(\Delta=10^2-4\cdot4\cdot(-6)=196\).
Roots: \(x=\tfrac{-10\pm14}{8}\Rightarrow x=-3,\,\tfrac12\).
\(<0\) between the roots.
âœ… Solution: \((-3,\,\tfrac12)\).





Quadratic: \(x^2+2x+4>0\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





\(\Delta=2^2-4\cdot1\cdot4=-12<0\) and \(a=1>0\) â‡’ the expression is always positive.
âœ… Solution: \(\mathbb{R}\).












NoteExercise 7 â€” Real radicals (radicand â‰¥ 0)




\(\sqrt{4-x^2}\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





We require \(4-x^2\ge0 \Rightarrow -2\le x\le 2\).
âœ… Solution: \([-2,2]\).





\(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{4-3x}}\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





The radicand must be positive (and the denominator \(\ne0\)): \(4-3x>0 \Rightarrow x<\tfrac43\).
âœ… Solution: \((-\infty,\tfrac43)\).





\(\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{x^2-x-12}}\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





We require \(x^2-x-12>0\Rightarrow(x-4)(x+3)>0\) â‡’ outside the roots.
âœ… Solution: \((-\infty,-3)\cup(4,\infty)\).












NoteExercise 8 â€” Positivity of rational functions




\(\dfrac{x}{x^2+4}>0\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





Denominator \(x^2+4>0\) for all \(x\). Sign of the fraction = sign of \(x\).
âœ… Solution: \((0,\infty)\).





\(\dfrac{x}{x^2-4}>0\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





Critical points: \(x=0,\pm2\) (undefined at \(\pm2\)). Sign chart â‡’ positive on \((-2,0)\) and \((2,\infty)\).
âœ… Solution: \((-2,0)\cup(2,\infty)\).





\(\dfrac{x+1}{x-3}>0\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





Zero: \(-1\). Asymptote: \(3\). Sign by intervals â‡’ \((-\infty,-1)\) and \((3,\infty)\).
âœ… Solution: \((-\infty,-1)\cup(3,\infty)\).





\(\dfrac{x^2-1}{x^2-3x}>0\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





\(\dfrac{(x-1)(x+1)}{x(x-3)}>0\), with \(x\ne0,3\). Critical points: \(-1,0,1,3\).
Signs â‡’ \((-\infty,-1)\cup(0,1)\cup(3,\infty)\).
âœ… Solution: \((-\infty,-1)\cup(0,1)\cup(3,\infty)\).












NoteExercise 9 â€” Describe and diagram the set (in \(\mathbb{R}\))




\(x^2<4\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





\(-2<x<2\).
âœ… Solution: \((-2,2)\).





\(x^2+3x-4>0\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





\((x+4)(x-1)>0\) â‡’ outside the roots.
âœ… Solution: \((-\infty,-4)\cup(1,\infty)\).





\(x^2+6x+8\le0\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





\((x+2)(x+4)\le0\) â‡’ between the roots, including them.
âœ… Solution: \([-4,-2]\).





\(x^2<5x+14\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





\(x^2-5x-14<0\Rightarrow(x-7)(x+2)<0\) â‡’ between the roots.
âœ… Solution: \((-2,7)\).





\(2x^2>x+6\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





\(2x^2-x-6>0\). \(\Delta=49\). Roots: \(-\tfrac32\) and \(2\).
\(>0\) outside.
âœ… Solution: \((-\infty,-\tfrac32)\cup(2,\infty)\).





\(6x^2+13x<5\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





\(6x^2+13x-5<0\). \(\Delta=289\). Roots: \(-\tfrac52\) and \(\tfrac13\).
\(<0\) between.
âœ… Solution: \((-\tfrac52,\,\tfrac13)\).





\(x^3+3x^2>10x\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





\(x(x^2+3x-10)=x(x+5)(x-2)>0\).
Sign chart with critical points \(-5,0,2\) â‡’
âœ… Solution: \((-5,0)\cup(2,\infty)\).

\(-4<2-x<7\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





Adding \(-2\): \(-6<-x<5\). Multiplying by \(-1\) (inequality flips): \(6>x>-5\).
âœ… Solution: \((-5,6)\).





\(\dfrac{2x-1}{x}<3\)







NoteStep-by-step solution





\[
\frac{2x-1}{x}-3=\frac{-x-1}{x}<0 \ \Longleftrightarrow\ \frac{x+1}{x}>0.
\] Critical points: \(-1,0\). Signs â‡’ positive on \((-\infty,-1)\) and \((0,\infty)\).
âœ… Solution: \((-\infty,-1)\cup(0,\infty)\).

NoteStep-by-step solution





\[

1.1 âœ¨ What Are Number Sets?
Number sets are groups of numbers that share common characteristics. The main ones we will use are:

Natural Numbers \((\mathbb{N})\): \(\{0, 1, 2, 3, \ldots\}\)
Used to count objects; they are the non-negative integers.
Integers \((\mathbb{Z})\): \(\{\ldots, -3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3, \ldots\}\)
Include all naturals, their negatives, and zero.
Rational Numbers \((\mathbb{Q})\): numbers that can be written as a fraction
\[
\mathbb{Q}=\left\{\frac{a}{b}\;\middle|\;a,b\in\mathbb{Z},\; b\neq 0\right\}.
\]
Examples: \(\tfrac{1}{2}\), \(-\tfrac{3}{4}\), \(5=\tfrac{5}{1}\).
Irrational Numbers \((\mathbb{R}\setminus\mathbb{Q})\): cannot be expressed as a fraction of integers; have infinite non-repeating decimals (e.g., \(\sqrt{2}\), \(\pi\), \(e\)).
Real Numbers \((\mathbb{R})\): all points on the real line; include rationals and irrationals.

1.3 ğŸ” ğŸ§  Learn More: What is an irrational number?






TipğŸ§  Learn More: What is an irrational number?





ğŸ”¢ An irrational is a real number that cannot be written as \(\dfrac{a}{b}\) with \(a,b\in\mathbb{Z}\) and \(b\neq 0\).
Its decimal expansion is infinite and non-repeating (e.g., \(\pi\), \(e\), \(\sqrt{2}\)).
They naturally appear in: the diagonal of a square (\(\sqrt{2}\)), circumference (\(\pi\)), exponential growth/logarithms (\(e\)).
Historically, the irrationality of \(\sqrt{2}\) shook the Pythagorean school.

text:
1.4 ğŸ“ The Pythagorean School and the â€œscandalâ€ of irrationals






NoteğŸ“ The Pythagorean School and Irrationals





Who were they? A philosopherâ€“mathematician community (6th century BC) who claimed that â€œeverything is numberâ€ (rational).
The crisis. The hypotenuse of an isosceles right triangle with legs of length 1 has length \(\sqrt{2}\), which is not rational.
The proof of the irrationality of \(\sqrt{2}\) is attributed to Hippasus.
Impact. The first blow to this worldview; it marked the beginning of the formal acceptance of irrationals, essential for the completeness of \(\mathbb{R}\).

1.13 ğŸ“š Properties of Number Sets
ğŸ”¸ Useful definitions

Closure: a set is closed under an operation when the result remains in the set.
Ex.: \(\mathbb{N}\) is closed under addition; \(\mathbb{Z}\) is closed under subtraction.
Density: a set is dense if between any two distinct elements there is another element of the same set.
Ex.: \(\mathbb{Q}\) is dense; also \(\mathbb{R}\setminus\mathbb{Q}\) is dense in \(\mathbb{R}\).


ğŸ”¹ Natural numbers \((\mathbb{N}=\{0,1,2,\ldots\})\)
Counting; closed under \(+\) and \(\cdot\); not closed under \(-\) or \(/\).
ğŸ”¹ Integers \((\mathbb{Z}=\{\ldots,-2,-1,0,1,2,\ldots\})\)
Include \(\mathbb{N}\); closed under \(+\), \(-\), \(\cdot\); not closed under \(/\).
ğŸ”¹ Rationals \((\mathbb{Q})\)
Fractions and finite/repeating decimals; closed under the four operations (with \(b\neq 0\)); dense.
ğŸ”¹ Irrationals \((\mathbb{R}\setminus\mathbb{Q})\)
Non-repeating infinite decimals; dense; not closed under \(+\) or \(\cdot\) (e.g., \(\sqrt{2}+(-\sqrt{2})=0\notin\) irrationals).
ğŸ”¹ Reals \((\mathbb{R})\)
\(\mathbb{Q}\cup(\mathbb{R}\setminus\mathbb{Q})\); represent the real line.
For \(a,b\in\mathbb{R}\), if \(b\neq 0\) then \(\tfrac{a}{b}\in\mathbb{R}\).

1.1 ğŸ§  Deep Dive: Proof that \(\sqrt{2}\) is not rational






NoteğŸ§  Proof by contradiction: \(\sqrt{2}\notin\mathbb{Q}\)





Proposition. \(\sqrt{2}\) is irrational.
Proof. Suppose, for contradiction, that \(\sqrt{2}=\frac{a}{b}\) with \(a,b\in\mathbb{Z}\), \(b\neq 0\), and \(\gcd(a,b)=1\).
Squaring: \(2=\frac{a^2}{b^2}\Rightarrow a^2=2b^2\). Thus, \(a^2\) is even, so \(a=2k\). Substituting:
\(4k^2=2b^2\Rightarrow b^2=2k^2\), hence \(b\) is even. Contradiction, since both \(a\) and \(b\) would be even \(\Rightarrow \gcd(a,b)\ge2\).
Therefore, \(\sqrt{2}\notin\mathbb{Q}\). \(\square\)

1.2 ğŸ§  Deep Dive: Comment on proof by contradiction






ImportantğŸ§  About the proof technique





The technique assumes the negation of what is to be proven and extracts a logical contradiction. In the case of \(\sqrt{2}\), the rationality hypothesis forces both \(a\) and \(b\) to be even, contradicting irreducibility. Hence, the hypothesis is false.

Uncountable: does not admit such a listing; it has â€œmoreâ€ elements than \(\mathbb{N}\). Example: \(\mathbb{R}\) (and therefore \(\mathbb{R}\setminus\mathbb{Q}\)).

ImportantğŸ§  Cantorâ€™s diagonal argument: \([0,1]\) is uncountable





Suppose all reals in \([0,1]\) are listed: \(x_1,x_2,\dots\), with decimal expansions \(x_i=0.a_{i1}a_{i2}\ldots\).
Construct \(y=0.b_1b_2\ldots\) by choosing \(b_n\neq a_{nn}\). Thus, \(y\) differs from every \(x_n\) at digit \(n\), so it is not on the list. Contradiction.
Therefore, \(\mathbb{R}\) (already within \([0,1]\)) is uncountable.

Write all pairs \((p,q)\in\mathbb{N}\times\mathbb{N}\) in a table;

Traverse by diagonals with sum \(p+q=k\) (for \(k=2,3,4,\ldots\));

List \(\tfrac{p}{q}\) only when \(\gcd(p,q)=1\) (irreducible) â†’ avoids repetitions.

Initial sequence (positives):
\[
\frac{1}{1},\ \frac{1}{2},\ \frac{2}{1},\ \frac{1}{3},\ \frac{3}{1},\ \frac{1}{4},\ \frac{2}{3},\ \frac{3}{2},\ \frac{4}{1},\ \ldots
\]
For negatives and \(0\), interleave signs and include \(0=\frac{0}{1}\).

Classical idea (see, for example, Courant & John).







Diagonal method â€” rationals

title: ğŸ§  ğŸ”¢ Module 1.2 AP: Number Sets â€” Advanced
section: 1.6 ğŸ§  Deep Dive: Finiteness of decimal representation
text:
1.6 ğŸ§  Deep Dive: Finiteness of decimal representation






ImportantğŸ§  Theorem: finite decimal â‡” denominator (in lowest terms) has only factors 2 and/or 5





If \(\tfrac{a}{b}\) is in lowest terms, then its decimal expansion is finite if and only if \(b\) has only prime factors \(2\) and \(5\).
Idea of the proof: write \(\tfrac{a}{b}\) with denominator \(10^n=2^n\cdot5^n\); this is only possible if \(b\) (already simplified) contains no primes other than \(2\) and \(5\).
Examples:
\(\tfrac{3}{8}=0.375\) (ok: \(8=2^3\)) Â· \(\tfrac{7}{20}=0.35\) (ok: \(20=2^2\cdot5\)) Â·
\(\tfrac{4}{15}=0.\overline{26}\) (has factor \(3\)) Â· \(\tfrac{5}{6}=0.\overline{83}\) (has factor \(3\)).

title: ğŸ§  ğŸ”¢ Module 1.2 AP: Number Sets â€” Advanced
section: 1.7 ğŸ§  Deep Dive: \(\mathbb{R}\) as a complete ordered field
text:
1.7 ğŸ§  Deep Dive: \(\mathbb{R}\) as a complete ordered field






NoteğŸ§  Structure of \(\mathbb{R}\)





Field \((\mathbb{R},+,\cdot)\): usual additive and multiplicative laws, distributivity, and inverses (except for \(0\) in multiplication).
Compatible total order \(\le\): trichotomy; \(a\le b\Rightarrow a+c\le b+c\); \(0\le a,0\le b\Rightarrow 0\le ab\).
Completeness (supremum axiom): every non-empty subset that is bounded above has a supremum in \(\mathbb{R}\).
This fails in \(\mathbb{Q}\).

title: ğŸ§  ğŸ”¢ Module 1.2 AP: Number Sets â€” Advanced
section: 1.8 ğŸ§  The completeness property: central example
text:
1.8 ğŸ§  The completeness property: central example






ImportantğŸ§  Example: \(\sup\) {\(x\in\mathbb{Q}\mid x^2<2\)}





Consider \(A=\{x\in\mathbb{Q}\mid x^2<2\}\). \(A\) is bounded above (for instance, by \(2\), or even by \(1.5\), \(1.42\), 9.9, etc.).
In \(\mathbb{Q}\), the supremum does not exist: the natural candidate would be \(\sqrt{2}\), but \(\sqrt{2}\notin\mathbb{Q}\).
In \(\mathbb{R}\), \(\sup A=\sqrt{2}\).














NoteğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» ğŸ Python â€” Visualization of {\(x\in\mathbb{Q}\mid x^2<2\)}






import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
from pathlib import Path
import os

# Domain and curve
x = np.linspace(0, 2, 400)
y = x**2

# Some rationals with x^2 < 2
rational_x = np.array([1.0, 1.2, 1.3, 1.4])
rational_y = rational_x**2

sqrt2 = np.sqrt(2)

plt.figure(figsize=(6, 4))
plt.plot(x, y, label=r'$y = x^2$')
plt.axhline(2, linestyle='--', label=r'$y = 2$')
plt.scatter(rational_x, rational_y, label=r'Some rationals with $x^2 < 2$')

# Mark supremum in â„
plt.axvline(sqrt2, linestyle='--', label=r'$\sup = \sqrt{2}$')
plt.text(sqrt2 + 0.02, 1, r'$\sqrt{2}$ (irrational)')

plt.title(r'Example: $\{x \in \mathbb{Q} \mid x^2 < 2\}$')
plt.xlabel('x'); plt.ylabel('y')
plt.grid(True); plt.legend(); plt.tight_layout()

# Save figure (for reuse in the site)
try:
    base = Path(__file__).parent.resolve()
except NameError:
    base = Path(os.getcwd()).resolve()
out = (base / ".." / "images" / "grafico_completude.png").resolve()
plt.savefig(out, dpi=150, bbox_inches="tight")

plt.show()

ImportantğŸ“ Worked Solutions






\(\mathbb{N}\), \(\mathbb{Z}\), \(\mathbb{Q}\): countable. \(\mathbb{R}\) and the positive irrationals: uncountable.

Construct a number that differs from the diagonal of a supposedly complete decimal list; the constructed number is not in the list.

Structure with the usual \(+,\times,\le\) and supremum axiom: every non-empty set bounded above has a least upper bound in \(\mathbb{R}\).

Assume \(\sqrt{2}=\tfrac{p}{q}\) in lowest terms \(\Rightarrow p,q\) both even \(\Rightarrow\) contradiction.

In the division \(p\div q\), there are at most \(q\) remainders; some remainder repeats \(\Rightarrow\) decimal finite or repeating.

An infinite non-repeating decimal means no remainder repeats \(\Rightarrow\) irrational.

Countable: there is a bijection with \(\mathbb{N}\). For \(\mathbb{Q}\): arrange via diagonals with gcd filter \(=1\).

\(\mathbb{N}\times\mathbb{N}\) is listed by diagonals \((1,1),(1,2),(2,1),(1,3),\ldots\); thus bijection with \(\mathbb{N}\).

\(A=\{x\in\mathbb{Q}\mid x^2<2\}\) is bounded above, but has no supremum in \(\mathbb{Q}\) (it would be \(\sqrt{2}\)).

Period 6. \(10^6x=142857.142857\ldots\); \(10^6x-x=142857\Rightarrow 999999x=142857\Rightarrow x=\tfrac{142857}{999999}=\tfrac{1}{7}\).

title: ğŸ“ ğŸ“Š Statistics Course: The Normal Distribution (Part 1): Introduction to the Normal Distribution
text:
1.1 ğŸ“ Standard Normal Curve
The normal curve, also known as the Gaussian distribution, is one of the most fundamental tools in statistics. It describes how certain variables are distributed around a mean, with most values concentrated near that mean and fewer values at the extremes.
When we talk about the standard normal curve, we are referring to a specific version of this distribution, with:


mean \(\mu = 0\)


standard deviation \(\sigma = 1\)


This standardization makes it easier to compare different datasets and forms the basis for many statistical procedures, such as probability calculations, hypothesis testing, and confidence interval construction.


1.1.1 ğŸ§  Why Is It So Important?
The standard normal curve is used to:

model natural phenomena (such as height, weight, measurement errors);
standardize data into z-scores;
build reference tables;
develop inferential reasoning in statistics.










Note





Normal Curve (or Gaussian Distribution): Represents a symmetric distribution around the mean. In the standard version, the mean is \(\mu = 0\) and the standard deviation \(\sigma = 1\). The area under the curve corresponds to the entirety of the observed population.

title: ğŸ“ ğŸ“Š Statistics Course: The Normal Distribution (Part 1): Introduction to the Normal Distribution
text:
1.2 ğŸ¯ Measuring the Invisible
We cannot always directly observe the characteristics of a population. In many cases, we deal with abstract concepts â€” such as intelligence, musical ability, productivity, or motivation â€” that cannot be measured in a direct and objective way.
However, even though they are â€œinvisible,â€ these characteristics leave traces in the data: exams, tests, evaluations, questionnaires, practical performance. This is where statistics comes in: it helps us infer what we cannot see from what we are able to measure.

It is assumed, for example, that these characteristics:

tend to cluster around the mean;
are rare at the extremes (very high or very low values);
can be represented by symmetric curves, such as the normal curve.









Tip



To estimate is to measure with uncertainty. The normal curve provides us with a way to describe this uncertainty with mathematical precision.

title: ğŸ“ ğŸ“Š Statistics Course: The Normal Distribution (Part 1): Introduction to the Normal Distribution
section: 1.3 ğŸ“ The Normal Curve: A Deeper Look
text:
1.3 ğŸ“ The Normal Curve: A Deeper Look
The normal curve can be understood as the graphical representation of a mathematical function called the probability density function.

The horizontal axis represents the measured values of the variable: \(x\).
The vertical axis indicates the height of the curve at each point: \(f(x)\), that is, the probability density.
The relationship between \(x\) and \(f(x)\) is described by the formula:

\[
\boxed{f(x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi\sigma^2}} \cdot e^{-\frac{(x - \mu)^2}{2\sigma^2}}}
\]
where:


\(\mu\) is the mean of the distribution,

\(\sigma\) is the standard deviation,

\(e\) is the base of the natural logarithm (approximately 2.718).

In the standard form, we have \(\mu = 0\) and \(\sigma = 1\).

For each value of \(x\), the function returns the height of the curve at that point.
The area under the curve between two values represents the probability that the random variable takes a value within that interval.

title: ğŸ“ ğŸ“Š Statistics Course: The Normal Distribution (Part 1): Introduction to the Normal Distribution
section: 1.4 ğŸ“ˆ Graphical Representation of the Normal Curve
text:
1.4 ğŸ“ˆ Graphical Representation of the Normal Curve









Note



Standard Normal Curve: The curve is centered at \(\mu = 0\) and the standard deviation is \(\sigma = 1\). The area under the curve represents the distribution of the population around the mean.

title: ğŸ“ ğŸ“Š Statistics Course: The Normal Distribution (Part 1): Introduction to the Normal Distribution
text:
1.5 ğŸ“ Empirical Rule â€” 68% - 95% - 99.7%
The Empirical Rule describes how data are distributed around the mean in a standard normal distribution.

About 68% of the data lie between \(\mu - 1\sigma\) and \(\mu + 1\sigma\)

About 95% of the data lie between \(\mu - 2\sigma\) and \(\mu + 2\sigma\)

About 99.7% of the data lie between \(\mu - 3\sigma\) and \(\mu + 3\sigma\)











Note



The Empirical Rule is a powerful visual tool. It allows us to quickly identify what is common and what is rare in a population that follows a normal distribution.

title: ğŸ“ ğŸ“Š Statistics Course: The Normal Distribution (Part 1): Introduction to the Normal Distribution
section: 1.6 ğŸ“Œ Parameters of the Normal Distribution
text:
1.6 ğŸ“Œ Parameters of the Normal Distribution
The normal distribution is not a single curve, but rather a family of curves. Each member of this family is fully described by two population parameters:

Mean \(\mu\): Indicates the center of the distribution. The curve is symmetric around this value.
Standard deviation \(\sigma\): Measures the dispersion of the data. Curves with larger \(\sigma\) are more spread out and flatter; with smaller \(\sigma\), they are more narrow and taller.







Note



In any normal distribution, the curve is perfectly symmetric: the left side is a mirror image of the right side with respect to the mean.



1.6.1 ğŸ¯ Why Are These Parameters Important?
By knowing \(\mu\) and \(\sigma\), we can:

Locate typical values of the population;
Calculate probabilities of values occurring within certain intervals;
Standardize data from different distributions using the transformation:

\[
\boxed{z = \frac{x - \mu}{\sigma}}
\]
This transformation converts any value \(x\) into a z-score, making it possible to use the standard normal distribution directly.










Note



Normal Curves with the Same Mean The mean defines the central position of the curves. The shape (height and width) is controlled exclusively by the standard deviation \(\sigma\).

title: ğŸ“ ğŸ“Š Statistics Course: The Normal Distribution (Part 1): Introduction to the Normal Distribution
text:
1.7 ğŸ“ Example: IQ Distribution (Stanfordâ€“Binet)
Letâ€™s apply the normal distribution to a practical case.
Suppose that IQ (Intelligence Quotient) scores follow a normal distribution with:

Mean \(\mu = 100\)

Standard deviation \(\sigma = 16\)




1.7.1 ğŸ§  Interpretation






Note



Interval of 1 Standard Deviation Around the Mean
The general formula to calculate this interval is:
\[
\mu \pm k\sigma
\]
In this example, with \(\mu = 100\), \(\sigma = 16\), and \(k = 1\):
\[
\mu - 1\sigma = 100 - 1 \times 16 = 84
\] \[
\quad \text{and} \quad
\] \[
\mu + 1\sigma = 100 + 1 \times 16 = 116
\]
Therefore, according to the Empirical Rule, about 68% of the population has an IQ between 84 and 116.



1.7.2 ğŸ“Š Visualization









Note



IQ Distribution â€” Interval of 1 Standard Deviation
The shaded area represents individuals with IQ between 84 and 116. According to the Empirical Rule, this interval contains about 68% of the population.



1.7.3 ğŸ’¡ Conclusion

The Stanfordâ€“Binet test is calibrated to follow this distribution.
The normal curve makes it possible to assess how common or rare an IQ score is.
Scores outside the interval \(\mu \pm 2\sigma\) (between 68 and 132) are already considered atypical.







Note



The normal distribution is useful for comparing individuals to the population mean and identifying exceptional performance.

title: ğŸ“ ğŸ“Š Statistics Course: The Normal Distribution (Part 1): Introduction to the Normal Distribution
section: 1.8 ğŸ“ Empirical Rule Applied to IQ Distribution
text:
1.8 ğŸ“ Empirical Rule Applied to IQ Distribution









Note





Empirical Rule Applied to IQ
The IQ distribution (with mean \(\mu = 100\) and standard deviation \(\sigma = 16\)) allows us to clearly visualize the Empirical Rule:


68% of individuals have IQ between 84 and 116 \((\mu \pm 1\sigma)\)


95% are between 68 and 132 \((\mu \pm 2\sigma)\)


99.7% are between 52 and 148 \((\mu \pm 3\sigma)\)


Each band of the curve represents a portion of the population and was drawn with non-overlapping colors to highlight their individual contributions.

title: ğŸ“ ğŸ“Š Statistics Course: The Normal Distribution (Part 1): Introduction to the Normal Distribution
section: 1.9 ğŸ§ª Example with Python Code: Visualizing the Empirical Rule
text:
1.9 ğŸ§ª Example with Python Code: Visualizing the Empirical Rule
Letâ€™s graphically represent an IQ distribution using the empirical rule. Suppose IQ scores follow a normal distribution with mean \(\mu = 100\) and standard deviation \(\sigma = 16\). The chart below shows the non-overlapping bands of the empirical rule:






NoteğŸ‘¨â€ğŸ’» ğŸ Python Code â€” generate the figure






import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Distribution parameters
mu = 100
sigma = 16
x = np.linspace(40, 160, 1000)
y = 1 / (np.sqrt(2 * np.pi) * sigma) * np.exp(- (x - mu)**2 / (2 * sigma**2))

# Separated bands of the empirical rule
bands = [
    {'label': '3Ïƒ: 52 to 68',   'x1': mu - 3*sigma, 'x2': mu - 2*sigma, 'color': '#FFC0CB'},
    {'label': '2Ïƒ: 68 to 84',   'x1': mu - 2*sigma, 'x2': mu - 1*sigma, 'color': '#ADD8E6'},
    {'label': '1Ïƒ: 84 to 100',  'x1': mu - 1*sigma, 'x2': mu,           'color': '#90EE90'},
    {'label': '1Ïƒ: 100 to 116', 'x1': mu,           'x2': mu + 1*sigma, 'color': '#90EE90'},
    {'label': '2Ïƒ: 116 to 132', 'x1': mu + 1*sigma, 'x2': mu + 2*sigma, 'color': '#ADD8E6'},
    {'label': '3Ïƒ: 132 to 148', 'x1': mu + 2*sigma, 'x2': mu + 3*sigma, 'color': '#FFC0CB'}
]

# Create figure (no figsize to use Quarto's fig-width/fig-height)
fig, ax = plt.subplots()
ax.plot(x, y, color='black')

# Fill bands
for band in bands:
    x_fill = np.linspace(band['x1'], band['x2'], 500)
    y_fill = 1 / (np.sqrt(2 * np.pi) * sigma) * np.exp(- (x_fill - mu)**2 / (2 * sigma**2))
    ax.fill_between(x_fill, y_fill, color=band['color'], label=band['label'])

# Mean line
ax.axvline(mu, color='blue', linestyle='--', linewidth=2, label='Mean (Î¼ = 100)')

# Customization
ax.set_title('IQ Distribution â€” Empirical Rule with Separated Bands')
ax.set_xlabel('IQ')
ax.set_ylabel('Probability Density')
ax.grid(True, linestyle="--", alpha=0.3)
ax.legend(loc='upper right')
plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()



IQ Distribution â€” Empirical Rule with separated bands.












Note





This chart highlights how IQ values are distributed around the mean, with colored areas representing:

Light green: 68% of individuals (84 to 116)
Light blue: 27% of individuals (68 to 84 and 116 to 132)
Light pink: 4.7% of individuals (52 to 68 and 132 to 148)

The dashed blue line marks the population mean.












NoteğŸ“Š R â€” generate figure with ggplot2

# Sequence of values

# Empirical Rule bands

IQ Distribution â€” Empirical Rule with ggplot2.












Note





In this chart, each interval of the normal curve represents a proportion of the population:

title: ğŸ“ ğŸ“Š Statistics Course: The Normal Distribution (Part 1): Introduction to the Normal Distribution
section: 1.10 ğŸ“ Foundation of the Empirical Rule
text:
1.10 ğŸ“ Foundation of the Empirical Rule
The Empirical Rule is based on the symmetric shape of the normal curve and on the areas under the curve, which represent probabilities.

The total area under the normal curve equals 1 (or 100%).
This area represents the probability of occurrence of values within specific intervals.
To simplify calculations, we use the standard normal distribution, with mean \(\mu = 0\) and standard deviation \(\sigma = 1\).







Tip



In the standard normal distribution, the probability of a value being between two points \(a\) and \(b\) is given by the integral of the density function between these limits.



1.10.1 ğŸ”¢ Probability Density Function of the Standard Normal
\[
\boxed{f(z) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{2\pi}}\, e^{-z^2/2}}
\]
\[
\boxed{P(a < Z < b) = \int_{a}^{b} f(z)\, dz}
\]

Based on this function, we obtain the following approximations:

\(P(-1 < Z < 1) \approx 68.27\%\)
\(P(-2 < Z < 2) \approx 95.45\%\)
\(P(-3 < Z < 3) \approx 99.73\%\)

These percentages give rise to the famous 68â€“95â€“99.7 Rule, used in descriptive statistics and inference to evaluate the dispersion of data around the mean in approximately normal distributions.









Note





Standard Normal Distribution and the Empirical Rule
The image illustrates the symmetric bands around the mean \(\mu = 0\):


68.27% of the values between \(-1\) and \(+1\) standard deviation;

95.45% between \(-2\) and \(+2\);

99.73% between \(-3\) and \(+3\).

The area under the curve represents the probability that the value \(Z\) lies within this interval.

text:
1.11 Functions for the Normal Distribution: Excel and R
We can calculate probabilities, cumulative values, and generate plots using specific functions:






NoteIn Excel

NORM.S.DIST(z, cumulative) â†’ Specific function for the standard normal distribution.
NORM.INV(probability, mean, standard_dev) â†’ Returns the value of \(x\) associated with a cumulative probability.
NORM.S.INV(probability) â†’ Returns the value \(z\) in the standard normal distribution.









NoteIn R

pnorm(x, mean, sd) â†’ Returns the cumulative probability up to \(x\).
qnorm(p, mean, sd) â†’ Returns the quantile \(x\) such that \(P(X \leq x) = p\).
rnorm(n, mean, sd) â†’ Generates a random sample of size \(n\).









Tip

section: 1.13 Practical Example â€“ Probability of IQ Below 120
text:
1.13 Practical Example â€“ Probability of IQ Below 120
Problem: What is the probability that a person has an IQ less than 120?
Suppose IQ scores follow a normal distribution with mean \(\mu = 100\) and standard deviation \(\sigma = 16\). We want to calculate:
\[
P(X < 120)
\]






NoteIn Excel



=NORM.DIST(120, 100, 16, TRUE) Result: \(\approx 0.8944\) or 89.44%








NoteIn R



pnorm(120, mean = 100, sd = 16) Result: \(\approx 0.8944\) or 89.44%


Interpretation: approximately 89.44% of the population has an IQ below 120, according to the assumed normal distribution.

title: ğŸ“ ğŸ“Š Statistics Course: The Normal Distribution (Part 1): Introduction to the Normal Distribution
section: 1.14 Example: Solving Without Excel or R â€” Using the z-Score
text:
1.14 Example: Solving Without Excel or R â€” Using the z-Score
We want to calculate the probability that a person has an IQ lower than 120, assuming that IQ scores follow a normal distribution with:

Mean \(\mu = 100\)

Standard deviation \(\sigma = 16\)


We want to find:
\[
P(X < 120)
\]


1.14.1 ğŸ§® Step 1: Standardization with the z-Score
To use the standard normal distribution table, we must first standardize the observed value (120):
\[
z = \frac{x - \mu}{\sigma} = \frac{120 - 100}{16} = 1.25
\]

text:
1.15 ğŸ“ Understanding the z-Score
The z-score is a standardization that transforms any value \(x\) from a normal distribution \(N(\mu, \sigma^2)\) into a value in the standard normal distribution \(N(0, 1)\), with mean 0 and standard deviation 1.
It tells us how many standard deviations the value \(x\) is above or below the mean \(\mu\).
The formula is:
\[
\boxed{z = \frac{x - \mu}{\sigma}}
\]


1.15.1 ğŸ” Interpretation:

If \(z = 0\): the value \(x\) is exactly at the mean \(\mu\).
If \(z > 0\): the value \(x\) is above the mean.
If \(z < 0\): the value \(x\) is below the mean.


1.15.2 ğŸ¯ Why Is It Useful?
The z-score unifies different distributions into a standard form, allowing us to:

Consult the Z Table of the standard normal distribution \(N(0,1)\);
Easily calculate cumulative probabilities;
Compare values across distributions with different means and standard deviations.


1.15.3 ğŸ“Š Visual Summary: Interpreting the z-Score
Suppose \(x = 124\), with mean \(\mu = 100\) and standard deviation \(\sigma = 16\). The z-score is calculated as:
\[
z = \frac{x - \mu}{\sigma} = \frac{124 - 100}{16} = 1.5
\]
This value represents the relative position of \(x\) in a standard normal distribution.


1.15.3.1 ğŸ”¹ Cumulative Area up to \(z = 1.5\)



Area up to z = 1.5

Approximately 93.32% of the values lie below \(x = 124\).

1.15.3.2 ğŸ”¹ Area Between \(-1.5 < Z < 1.5\)



Area between -1.5 and 1.5

Approximately 86.64% of the values are within 1.5 standard deviations of the mean, on both sides.

1.15.3.3 ğŸ”¹ Area to the Right of \(z = 1.5\)



Area to the right of z = 1.5

Only 6.68% of the distribution lies above \(x = 124\).

1.15.3.4 âœ… Conclusion
The z-score allows us to:

Standardize values from different distributions;
Calculate probabilities using the Z Table or software;
Visualize the relative position of a value in relation to the mean.


ğŸ’¡ Essential Summary:
\[
\boxed{z = \frac{x - \mu}{\sigma}}
\]
This formula is the bridge between any value \(x\) from a normal distribution and its standardized position on the \(N(0,1)\) curve.

We can also perform the inverse of standardization:

1.20 ğŸ”„ Visualizing \(P(Z < -1.25)\) with Symmetry
The standard normal distribution is symmetric around \(z = 0\). This means that the areas under the curve at the same distance from the mean are equal:

The area to the left of \(z = -1.25\) is equal to the area to the right of \(z = 1.25\).
Thus, we can write:

\[
P(Z < -1.25) = P(Z > 1.25)
\]
And since:
\[
P(Z > 1.25) = 1 - P(Z < 1.25)
\]
We conclude that:
\[
P(Z < -1.25) = 1 - P(Z < 1.25)
\]



Standard normal distribution: symmetry between \(P(Z < -1.25)\) and \(P(Z > 1.25)\)

Situation: Suppose IQ scores follow a normal distribution with parameters:

text:
1.2 ğŸ“ Comparing Performances with the z-Score
Initial situation:

Student A scored 80 on a test with \(\mu=70,\; \sigma=5\).
Student B scored 8 on a test with \(\mu=6,\; \sigma=1\).

Calculation of z-scores:
\[
z_A = \frac{80-70}{5} = 2.0
\qquad
z_B = \frac{8-6}{1} = 2.0
\]
ğŸ“Œ Conclusion: Both students performed 2 standard deviations above the mean of their classes. In other words, their relative performance was equivalent.







NoteğŸ§  ğŸ“– Exercise 2 â€” Comparing Performances with the z-Score



Situation:

Student A scored 65 on a test with \(\mu=60,\; \sigma=4\).
Student B scored 7 on a test with \(\mu=5.5,\; \sigma=1\).

Task: 1. Calculate the z-score for both students. 2. Compare the values. 3. Interpret: which one stood out more relative to their class average?
ğŸ’¡ Hint: the larger the \(z\), the better the relative performance.








ImportantğŸ§  ğŸ” Solution â€” Exercise 2





Student A:
\[
z_A = \frac{65-60}{4} = \frac{5}{4} = 1.25
\]
Student B:
\[
z_B = \frac{7-5.5}{1} = \frac{1.5}{1} = 1.5
\]
ğŸ“Œ Conclusion: Student B obtained \(z_B=1.5\), greater than \(z_A=1.25\). Therefore, Student B showed better relative performance compared to their class.









Warningâœï¸ğŸ“„ Summary â€” Normal Distribution and z-Score




Normal Distribution:

\[
\boxed{\, f(x)=\tfrac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi \sigma^2}} \, e^{-\tfrac{(x-\mu)^2}{2 \sigma^2}} \,}
\]

Standard Normal Distribution (\(\mu=0,\; \sigma=1\)):

\[
\boxed{\, f(z)=\tfrac{1}{\sqrt{2 \pi}} \, e^{-z^2/2} \,}
\]

z-Score (standardization):

\[
\boxed{\, z=\tfrac{x-\mu}{\sigma} \,}
\]

Original value from \(z\):

\[
\boxed{\, x=\mu+z\sigma \,}
\]

Empirical Rule (68â€“95â€“99.7):

\(68\%\): between \(\mu \pm 1\sigma\)
\(95\%\): between \(\mu \pm 2\sigma\)
\(99.7\%\): between \(\mu \pm 3\sigma\)

section: 1.2 ğŸ“ˆ â“ What Is an Approximately Normal Distribution?
text:
1.2 ğŸ“ˆ â“ What Is an Approximately Normal Distribution?
We call approximately normal distributions those variables that, even without following the normal curve exactly, present enough characteristics for statistical methods based on normality to be applied.
ğŸ‘‰ Main characteristics:


Bell-shaped form and symmetry around the mean.
Higher concentration of observations close to the mean, with few extreme occurrences.
Most values concentrated within 1 to 2 standard deviations of the mean.

â— Important notes:

Not every variable needs to be perfectly normal for us to apply statistical tests.

Small asymmetries or irregularities are usually tolerable.
Many real-world distributions are not exactly normal, but rather approximately normal.

ğŸ“Œ Typical examples:

Adult height.
Service times in operations.
Industrial processes under statistical control.







NoteğŸ“ˆ ğŸ“ Examples of Distributions: Normal and Non-Normal



âœ… Approximately normal variables:

Adult height within the same population.
Service time in standardized operations.
Measurement errors under controlled conditions.

âŒ Non-normally distributed variables:

Household income (right-skewed â€” positive skewness).
Number of children per family (discrete, skewed).
Lifetime of electronic equipment (long right tail).

ğŸ“Œ Note: Some variables can approach normality after transformations, such as logarithm or square root.









NoteğŸ“ˆ ğŸ“ Real-World Examples of Approximate Normality



Examples of variables with approximately normal distribution:

Heights of university students.
Phone service times in standardized call centers.
Weights of newborns in hospitals.
Scores on standardized tests (e.g., proficiency exams).
Measurement errors in controlled physics experiments.
Retirement ages in large populations.

â— Important: Even if the actual distribution is not perfectly normal, a normal approximation is often sufficient for practical applications and statistical inference.

1.3 ğŸ“ˆ â“ What Is a Qâ€“Q Plot?
ğŸ“Š The Qâ€“Q Plot (Quantileâ€“Quantile Plot) is a chart used to compare the distribution of sample data with a theoretical distribution â€” usually the normal.
ğŸ¯ Objectives:

Assess whether the data approximately follow a normal distribution.
Identify relevant deviations, such as skewness or heavy tails.

ğŸ” How to interpret:

If the points align close to a diagonal straight line, the data are approximately normal.

Systematic deviations (curvature or tail departures) indicate lack of normality.

ğŸ“Œ Note: The Qâ€“Q Plot is especially useful with large samples, since small imperfections are expected and do not compromise the overall interpretation.







NoteğŸ“ˆ ğŸ“ Visual Example â€” Histogram of a Normal Distribution



ğŸ‘‰ Situation:

Sample of 200 adult heights.
Observed mean: \(170\) cm.
Observed standard deviation: \(8\) cm.

ğŸ“ˆ Chart:


Chart generated in R from 200 simulated observations of \(X \sim \mathcal N(170,\,8^2)\).

ğŸ” Interpretation: The histogram shows a bell shape, symmetric around the mean. Small variations are expected, but the approximation to the normal distribution is very good.








NoteğŸ“ˆ ğŸ“ Visual Example â€” Qâ€“Q Plot (Levine)



ğŸ‘‰ Situation: The same sample of 200 adult heights (\(\mu=170,\; \sigma=8\)) was used to build the Qâ€“Q plot.
ğŸ“ˆ Chart:


Chart generated in R with 200 simulated observations of \(X \sim \mathcal N(170,\,8^2)\).

ğŸ” Interpretation:

When the points align approximately along the straight line, we conclude that the distribution is approximately normal.

Small fluctuations are expected in real samples and do not invalidate the analysis.









NoteGenerating Plots in R: Histogram and Qâ€“Q Plot





ğŸ¯ Objective: Generate a sample of heights and visualize the histogram and the Qâ€“Q plot directly in RStudio.

# Generate the sample of heights
set.seed(123) # Ensures reproducibility
heights <- rnorm(200, mean = 170, sd = 8)

# Display the Histogram

TipğŸ” Why visualize plots before the analysis?

Applying statistical tests without this prior check may lead to misleading or statistically invalid conclusions. Visualization allows you to detect patterns, deviations, and anomalies that numbers alone may not revealâ€”therefore, it is a critical step in the data analysis workflow.

title: ğŸ“˜ Module 1.3 AP: Absolute Value and Modular Inequalities
text:
â† Back to Course Summary ğŸ“ğŸ§® Â· â† Math Courses Â· â† Math Section
ğŸ¯ Previous Post: ğŸ‘‰ 1.3 Intervals and Inequalities







NoteğŸ¯ Learning Objectives




Define absolute value (modulus) and interpret it geometrically.

Present fundamental properties of the modulus.

Introduce and apply the triangle inequality.

Solve inequalities involving absolute value.

Reinforce learning with examples and exercises.





1 Definition of Absolute Value






NoteğŸ“– Definition



The absolute value (or modulus) of a real number \(x\) is defined as:
\[
|x| =
\begin{cases}
x, & \text{if } x \ge 0, \\
-x, & \text{if } x < 0.
\end{cases}
\]





2 Geometric Interpretation

The absolute value represents the distance from \(x\) to the origin on the real line.

Therefore, \(|x|\ge 0\) for every \(x \in \mathbb{R}\).









3 Properties of Absolute Value






ImportantğŸ“ Main Properties




\(|x|\ge 0\) and \(|x|=0 \iff x=0\).

\(|xy|=|x|\cdot|y|\).

\(|\dfrac{x}{y}|=\dfrac{|x|}{|y|}\), if \(y\ne0\).

\(|x+y|\le |x|+|y|\) (triangle inequality).










NoteğŸ§¾ Proof of the Properties






(1) By definition, \(|x|\) is the distance to the origin. Distance is never negative, and it is zero only when the point itself is the origin (\(x=0\)).
(2) Let \(x,y\in\mathbb{R}\). Since the sign of a product is the product of the signs,
\[
|xy| = (\pm x)\cdot(\pm y) = |x|\cdot |y|.
\]
(3) For \(y\ne0\), simply divide the equality from the previous property:
\[
|x/y| = \frac{|x|}{|y|}.
\]
(4) Triangle Inequality: from the geometric interpretation, \(|x+y|\) represents the distance between \(0\) and \(x+y\). This distance can never exceed the sum of the distances from \(x\) and \(y\) to \(0\). Formally:
\[
|x+y|^2 = (x+y)^2 = x^2 + 2xy + y^2 \le (|x|+|y|)^2,
\] which implies \(|x+y|\le |x|+|y|\).







4 Worked Examples






NoteğŸ§® Example 1



Solve: \[
|x| = 3
\]






NoteSolution





By definition:
- If \(x\ge0\), then \(|x|=x=3 \Rightarrow x=3\).
- If \(x<0\), then \(|x|=-x=3 \Rightarrow x=-3\).
âœ… Solution: \(\{-3,3\}\).












NoteğŸ§® Example 2



Solve: \[
|x-2| < 5
\]






NoteSolution





\(|x-2|<5 \iff -5 < x-2 < 5 \iff -3 < x < 7\).
âœ… Solution: \((-3,7)\).








5 Absolute Value Inequalities






NoteğŸ“– Definition



An absolute value inequality is an inequality involving absolute value, such as: \[
|f(x)| \{<, \le, >, \ge\} a
\] with \(a\ge0\).
The solution depends on the piecewise definition of the modulus.





6 Practice Exercises






NoteğŸ“ Exercises




Solve: \(|x+1|\le4\).

Solve: \(|2x-3|>5\).

Solve: \(|x^2-1|<3\).

Verify whether \(|x+y|\le |x|+|y|\) for \(x=2, y=-5\).










Importantâœ… Answer Key






\(-5\le x+1\le4 \Rightarrow -6\le x\le3\).

\(|2x-3|>5 \Rightarrow 2x-3>5\) or \(2x-3<-5\) â‡’ \(x>4\) or \(x<-1\).

\(|x^2-1|<3 \Rightarrow -3<x^2-1<3 \Rightarrow -2<x^2<4\). Since \(x^2\ge0\), we get \(0\le x^2<4 \Rightarrow -2<x<2\).

\(|2+(-5)|=|-3|=3\) and \(|2|+|{-5}|=2+5=7\). Indeed, \(3\le7\).

1.1 âœ¨ What is Calculus?

1.1.1 ğŸŒ± Initial Intuition
Imagine a car on the road: the speedometer shows how the speed is changing right now; the total distance depends on adding up small segments.
That is the spirit of calculus: studying change and accumulation in the real world.


1.1.2 ğŸ“ Mathematical Formulation (concise)

Change â†’ rates of variation (derivatives).

Accumulation â†’ totals and areas (integrals).

Limit â†’ the formal basis that gives precision to the â€œinstantaneousâ€ and the â€œcontinuousâ€.

title: ğŸ§  Module 1.1: What is Calculus? History and Applications
section: 1.2 The Two Fundamental Problems of Calculus
text:
1.2 The Two Fundamental Problems of Calculus

1.2.1 ğŸŒ± Intuition: Tangents and Areas

Tangent problem: what is the slope of a curve at a point?

Area problem: what is the area of a region bounded by curves?



1.2.2 ğŸ“ Mathematical Formulation

Tangent at \(A=(a,f(a))\): the slope of the tangent is the value towards which the secants converge when the second point approaches \(A\).

Area on \([a,b]\): the area under \(y=f(x)\) is the value towards which the sums of small rectangles converge as we refine the partition.

section: 1.3 ğŸ” Visual Motivation â€” The Tangent Problem
text:
1.3 ğŸ” Visual Motivation â€” The Tangent Problem
We use the function \(y=e^x\) at the point \(A(0,1)\). In the figure, secant lines \((Aâ€“B, Aâ€“C, Aâ€“D)\) â€œrotateâ€ until they become the green line, which represents the tangent at \(A\).
Figure â€” Tangent approximation by secants for \(y=e^x\)






1.3.1 ğŸ§® Mini Numerical Example (without limit notation)
For \(y=e^x\) at \(x=0\), consider the secant between \(x=0\) and \(x=h\).
The slope of this secant is \[
m(h)=\frac{e^{h}-e^{0}}{h}=\frac{e^{h}-1}{h}.
\]

title: ğŸ§  Module 1.1: What is Calculus? History and Applications
section: 1.5 ğŸ“œ A Brief History of Calculus
text:
1.5 ğŸ“œ A Brief History of Calculus

Archimedes (3rd century BC): method of exhaustion (areas and volumes) â€” seed of integral calculus.

Fermat (17th century): techniques for tangents â€” seed of differential calculus.

Newton (1643â€“1727): focused on motion and Physics; called derivatives fluxions.

Leibniz (1646â€“1716): clear and general notation (symbols we still use today).







TipFundamental Theorem of Calculus (idea)



Later we will see that change (derivatives) and accumulation (integrals) are connected by a central result â€” the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus â€” which unifies the subject.

title: ğŸ§  Module 1.1: What is Calculus? History and Applications
text:
1.6 âœ… Wrapping Up the Introduction

Calculus answers two universal questions:

How fast is something changing right now? (tangents/derivatives)

How much has accumulated over an interval? (areas/integrals)


In this opening, we avoided formal symbols of limits/derivatives/integrals â€” focusing on visual and historical intuition.

Formalization will come step by step, always connected to figures and numerical examples.

Part 1 â€” Before the Quantum Revolution




1.2.1 ğŸ“š The Problem of Light and Energy
At the end of the 19th century, physics was considered practically complete. Lord Kelvin even stated that only a few details remained to be adjusted in the equations of classical physics.
The great theories â€” Newtonian mechanics, Maxwellâ€™s electromagnetism, and thermodynamics â€” seemed to describe the world with precision. But three experimental anomalies emerged that shook this confidence:


1.2.1.1 ğŸ”¥ The Ultraviolet Catastrophe
The radiation emitted by a blackbody â€” an ideal object that absorbs all incident radiation â€” followed a well-behaved pattern at low frequencies, but classical physics predictions exploded at high frequencies:

The Rayleighâ€“Jeans theory predicted that radiated energy increased indefinitely with frequency;

This led to an absurd result: infinite energy for any hot body!

This impasse became known as the ultraviolet catastrophe.



Blackbody radiation at different temperatures



Source: Wikimedia Commons â€” License CC BY-SA 3.0

â¡ï¸ Max Planck (1900) solved the impasse with a radical idea:
Energy is not emitted continuously, but in discrete packets, called quanta.
The proposed formula was: \[
E = h \nu
\] Where:

\(h \approx 6{,}626 \times 10^{-34}\ \text{J}\cdot\text{s}\) is Planckâ€™s constant;

\(\nu\) is the frequency of the radiation.

ğŸ” This proposal marked the beginning of energy quantization, a concept alien to classical physics.



1.2.1.2 âš¡ The Photoelectric Effect
Another inexplicable phenomenon was the emission of electrons by certain metals when illuminated by light.

Classical physics predicted that increasing the light intensity would always cause electron emission;

However, it was observed that without a minimum frequency, no electrons were emitted, regardless of intensity!

â¡ï¸ Albert Einstein (1905) proposed that light was composed of particles â€” photons â€” with energy also given by \(E = h\nu\).
Only photons with sufficient energy (high frequency) could eject electrons.
ğŸ’¡ This explanation, based on light quanta, confirmed the quantization of radiation.
Einstein received the Nobel Prize in 1921 for this work.




Photoelectric Effect


Photons (red waves) strike a metallic surface and cause the ejection of electrons.




1.2.1.3 ğŸŒŒ Bohrâ€™s Atom
The emission spectrum of hydrogen displayed discrete lines â€” as if electrons could only occupy certain energy levels.
â¡ï¸ Niels Bohr (1913) proposed an atomic model in which electrons:

Orbit the nucleus in quantized energy levels;

Only emit or absorb light when they jump between these levels.

This theory explained why only certain frequencies appeared in spectra:
\[
\Delta E = E_2 - E_1 = h\nu
\]
ğŸ“Œ Bohrâ€™s theory united the concepts of quantization with atomic structure â€” another blow to classical physics.




Bohr Model: quantized levels


The electron jumps from the second to the first energy level, emitting a photon (purple arrow).





1.2.2 ğŸ§¨ A System in Crisis
These three phenomena â€” blackbody radiation, the photoelectric effect, and atomic spectra â€” deeply challenged traditional physics:

Light behaved like a particle;

Energy came in discrete amounts;

Atoms had â€œquantizedâ€ structures.


ğŸ§© The consistency between these ideas and experiments pointed to a new physical reality.







NoteThe 20th Century demanded a new theory



And it finally emerged in 1925, breaking with centuries of classical intuition.
With decisive contributions from Heisenberg, SchrÃ¶dinger, Born, Dirac, and others, Quantum Mechanics was born â€” a scientific revolution as profound as those of Copernicus and Newton.

From then on, understanding the atom meant rethinking reality.

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§¬ 100 Years of Quantum Mechanics (1925â€“2025)
text:
1.3 Part 2 â€” The Revolution Begins (1925)




Part 2 â€” The Revolution Begins (1925)




1.3.1 âš›ï¸ Heisenberg and Matrix Mechanics
In the summer of 1925, Werner Heisenberg, then only 23 years old, introduced a radical new approach to describing atoms. He decided:

ğŸ” â€œPhysics must be based only on what can be directly observed.â€

Instead of trying to visualize electronic orbits â€” as in Bohrâ€™s model â€” Heisenberg focused on measurable values, such as frequencies and intensities of emission spectra.

ğŸ§  With the support of Max Born and Pascual Jordan, Heisenberg developed a new mathematical formulation:
Matrix Mechanics, in which physical quantities are represented by matrices â€” structures that, when multiplied, may not obey commutativity:
\[
\hat{A} \hat{B} \neq \hat{B} \hat{A}
\]
âš ï¸ This was shocking: in the quantum world, the order of operations matters!



1.3.2 ğŸ”„ Physical Consequences
This non-commutative behavior foreshadowed one of the pillars of quantum physics:
the Uncertainty Principle, formulated by Heisenberg two years later (in 1927).

ğŸ’¡ Instead of well-defined trajectories, the new theory predicted transition probabilities between states â€” a more uncertain, yet measurable world.




1.3.3 ğŸ“Œ A New Paradigm
The proposal was bold, abstract, and initially hard to accept.
But it successfully reproduced atomic spectra and matched experimental data.
ğŸŒŸ In 1925, Quantum Mechanics was formally born â€” inaugurating an era in which particle behavior would be described by non-classical mathematical structures.

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§¬ 100 Years of Quantum Mechanics (1925â€“2025)
text:
1.4 ğŸ§® Observables and Matrix Mechanics

1.4.1 ğŸ” What are observables?
In quantum mechanics, observables are measurable physical quantities of a system, such as:

position (\(x\)),

momentum (\(p\)),

energy (\(E\)),

spin,

angular momentum,

particle number, etc.


In classical physics, each observable is a real number that can be measured precisely â€” for example, a body has mass \(m = 2{,}0\,\mathrm{kg}\) and position \(x = 1{,}5\,\mathrm{m}\).

In quantum physics, each observable is represented by a mathematical operator (or a matrix, in the case of matrix mechanics), and measurement does not return a fixed value but rather a probabilistic outcome.



1.4.2 ğŸ§  Heisenbergâ€™s Proposal
Werner Heisenberg proposed completely abandoning any attempt to describe trajectories or imagine what is â€œhappening behind the scenesâ€ of measurements.

He decided to base the theory only on quantities that can be experimentally observed: transitions between energy levels.

These transitions can be described by frequencies \(\omega_{mn}\), associated with the emission or absorption of photons when the system goes from state \(m\) to state \(n\).



1.4.3 ğŸ“ Matrices Enter the Scene
When trying to organize these transitions, Max Born realized that the values associated with observables formed tables of numbers with two entries: from one state \(m\) to another \(n\).

These tables had the structure of matrices: an observable becomes a matrix \(\hat{A} = [A_{mn}]\), where each element represents the â€œlinkâ€ between two quantum states.

These matrices obey non-commutative multiplication rules, that is:
\[
\hat{A}\hat{B} \neq \hat{B}\hat{A}
\]
This unusual property reflects a fundamental feature of the quantum world.



1.4.4 ğŸ”„ Example: Position and Momentum
In classical mechanics, position \(x\) and momentum \(p\) are independent quantities.
But in quantum mechanics, they are related by a fundamental commutation relation:
\[
[\hat{x}, \hat{p}] = \hat{x}\hat{p} - \hat{p}\hat{x} = i\hbar
\]
This relation is the mathematical basis of Heisenbergâ€™s Uncertainty Principle, which states:

It is not possible to know with arbitrary precision both the position and the momentum of a particle at the same time.




1.4.5 ğŸ§  Impact of Matrix Mechanics
Matrix mechanics was:

The first coherent mathematical formulation of quantum mechanics;

Completely different from classical mechanics;

Capable of successfully predicting atomic spectra and energy transitions;

Initially considered strange and abstract â€” until SchrÃ¶dinger showed that his wave mechanics was equivalent.

Quantum Mechanics

Measurement

\(AB = BA\)

Examples

\(\hat{x}, \hat{p}, \hat{H}\)






1.4.7 ğŸ§­ Conclusion

Matrix mechanics introduced the idea that microscopic reality is not deterministic, but probabilistic and governed by non-commutative algebraic relations between observables.

This approach was essential for the emergence of the modern formalism of Quantum Mechanics, still used today in particle physics, quantum chemistry, and emerging technologies such as quantum computing.

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§¬ 100 Years of Quantum Mechanics (1925â€“2025)
section: 1.5 Part 3 â€” SchrÃ¶dinger and the Wave Function
text:
1.5 Part 3 â€” SchrÃ¶dinger and the Wave Function




Part 3 â€” SchrÃ¶dinger and the Wave Function




1.5.1 ğŸŒŠ The SchrÃ¶dinger Equation
In 1926, Erwin SchrÃ¶dinger proposed a new approach to describe the behavior of particles in the microscopic world â€” using differential equations inspired by wave theory.
The equation that bears his name is one of the pillars of Quantum Mechanics:
\[
i\hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \Psi(x, t) = \hat{H} \Psi(x, t)
\]
Where:

\(i\) is the imaginary unit;

\(\hbar\) is the reduced Planck constant (\(\hbar = \frac{h}{2\pi}\));

\(\Psi(x, t)\) is the particleâ€™s wave function;

\(\hat{H}\) is the Hamiltonian operator (total energy of the system).




1.5.2 âš™ï¸ What is the operator \(\hat{H}\)?
The Hamiltonian \(\hat{H}\) is the operator that represents the total energy of a quantum system.
In the SchrÃ¶dinger equation:
\[
i\hbar \frac{\partial}{\partial t} \Psi(x, t) = \hat{H} \Psi(x, t)
\]
the operator \(\hat{H}\) governs the time evolution of the wave function \(\Psi(x, t)\). It acts on the wave function like an instruction: it tells how the state of the system changes over time.



1.5.3 ğŸ”¬ Physical Interpretation

\(\hat{H}\) represents the sum of kinetic energy and potential energy of the particle (or system of particles);

When applied to \(\Psi\), it â€œextractsâ€ information about the energy content of the quantum state;

Its eigenvalues \(E_n\) are the possible energy levels of the system:

\[
\hat{H} \Psi_n = E_n \Psi_n
\]
This equation is called the time-independent SchrÃ¶dinger equation (or the Hamiltonian eigenvalue problem).



1.5.4 ğŸ“ Classic Example: Particle in One Dimension
For a particle of mass \(m\) in one dimension, subject to a potential \(V(x)\), the Hamiltonian is:
\[
\hat{H} = -\frac{\hbar^2}{2m} \frac{d^2}{dx^2} + V(x)
\]

The first term represents the kinetic energy (with the momentum operator \(\hat{p} = -i\hbar \frac{d}{dx}\));

The second term, \(V(x)\), is the potential energy.




1.5.5 ğŸ§  Fundamental Role in the Theory

The Hamiltonian is the generator of time evolution;

It is essential in the formulation of bound systems (such as the hydrogen atom), many-body systems, and in relativistic quantum mechanics (as in the Dirac equation);

It also appears in the formalism of quantum mechanics in Hilbert spaces, statistical mechanics, and quantum field theory.

\(\hat{H}\)

Role

Appears inâ€¦
SchrÃ¶dinger equation, quantum theory, QED, etc.






1.5.7 ğŸ§² In Summary

The operator \(\hat{H}\) is the dynamic heart of quantum mechanics.
It describes how a systemâ€™s state evolves over time and what possible energy values we can observe.





The Hamiltonian Operator \(\hat{H}\)


The operator \(\hat{H}\) generates the time evolution of the quantum system, being composed of kinetic and potential energy. It appears at the center of the SchrÃ¶dinger equation, driving the dynamics of the wave function.



1.5.8 ğŸ“Œ Physical Interpretation
SchrÃ¶dingerâ€™s great innovation was to treat the particle as a matter wave, instead of a point with a well-defined trajectory.
The function \(\Psi(x, t)\), though complex, contains all the information about the system.

ğŸ¯ The square modulus of the wave function, \(|\Psi(x, t)|^2\), represents the probability density of finding the particle at position \(x\) at time \(t\).

This probabilistic interpretation marked a rupture with classical determinism.



1.5.9 ğŸ”„ Two Paths, One Destination
At the same time, Heisenbergâ€™s matrix mechanics and SchrÃ¶dingerâ€™s wave mechanics seemed like very different proposals:

Heisenberg worked with abstract matrices and observables;

SchrÃ¶dinger described waves evolving in spacetime.

ğŸ’¡ But it was soon proven that both approaches were equivalent â€” simply different mathematical languages describing the same physical phenomena.



1.5.10 ğŸ“ˆ A New Universe
With the SchrÃ¶dinger equation, it became possible to predict the behavior of complex quantum systems:

Atoms with multiple electrons;

Molecules;

Bound states and quantized energy.

ğŸ”¬ This formulation enabled a giant leap in the understanding of matter â€” and paved the way for technologies such as semiconductors, lasers, and even quantum computing.




Wave Function


The function \(\Psi(x, t)\) may take complex values, but its squared modulus, \(|\Psi(x, t)|^2\), provides the probability density of finding the particle.

text:
1.6 Part 4 â€” Uncertainty and Paradox




Part 4 â€” Uncertainty and Paradox




1.6.1 ğŸ”„ The Uncertainty Principle
In 1927, Werner Heisenberg presented one of the most revolutionary ideas of modern physics: the Uncertainty Principle.
\[
\Delta x \cdot \Delta p \geq \frac{\hbar}{2}
\]
This means that the more precisely we know the position (\(\Delta x\)) of a particle, the less we know about its momentum (\(\Delta p\)) â€” and vice versa.

âš ï¸ This uncertainty is not a flaw of the instruments, but a fundamental limitation of nature.




1.6.2 ğŸ¯ What Does This Change?
In classical physics, we can, in principle, measure everything with infinite precision.
But in the quantum world, the very idea of â€œknowing everything about a particleâ€ ceases to make sense.
ğŸ” Uncertainty is not a defect of the theory, but a consequence of the mathematical structure of quantum mechanics â€” linked to the non-commutativity of observables:
\[
[\hat{x}, \hat{p}] = i\hbar
\]



1.6.3 ğŸ± SchrÃ¶dingerâ€™s Cat
In 1935, Erwin SchrÃ¶dinger proposed a thought experiment to illustrate the conceptual problems of quantum mechanics: the famous SchrÃ¶dingerâ€™s Cat.

Imagine a cat locked in a box with a mechanism that depends on the decay of a radioactive atom (a random quantum event).

If the atom decays, poison is released and the cat dies. Otherwise, the cat lives.



1.6.4 â“ The Paradox
According to the most common quantum interpretation (Copenhagen), while the box remains closed, the system is in a superposition of two states:

cat alive

cat dead

ğŸ§© Only when the box is opened and observed does the state collapse into one of the possibilities.



1.6.5 ğŸ’¬ Deep Reflections
This paradox raises fundamental questions:

Does the wave function describe reality itself or just our knowledge of it?

Does the observer play an active role in defining reality?

Is there an objective reality before measurement?


These questions remain at the heart of quantum mechanics interpretations to this day.





SchrÃ¶dingerâ€™s Cat â€” Quantum Superposition


While the box is closed, the cat is in a state of superposition: alive and dead at the same time, until observation occurs.

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§¬ 100 Years of Quantum Mechanics (1925â€“2025)
text:
1.7 Part 5 â€” Interpretations and Entanglement




Part 5 â€” Interpretations and Entanglement







Interpretations of Quantum Mechanics


On the left, the Copenhagen interpretation: the wave function collapses upon observation.
On the right, the Many Worlds interpretation: each possibility generates a parallel universe.


1.7.1 ğŸ›ï¸ Copenhagen vs.Â Many Worlds
Since the birth of Quantum Mechanics, one crucial question remains:
What exactly does the wave function mean?

SchrÃ¶dingerâ€™s equation predicts how \(\Psi(x,t)\) evolves.
But what happens when a measurement is made?

Two major schools of thought emerged to try to answer:


1.7.1.1 ğŸ›ï¸ Copenhagen Interpretation
Formulated by Bohr and Heisenberg, it is the most traditional.

The wave function represents our knowledge about the system;

The collapse of the wave function occurs at the moment of measurement;

Before that, the system is in a superposition of states.


ğŸ§© Reality, therefore, is not defined until it is observed.

This interpretation works very well in practice, but raises profound philosophical questions:
What counts as â€œmeasurementâ€? Does the observer alter reality?



1.7.1.2 ğŸŒŒ Many Worlds Interpretation (Everett, 1957)
Hugh Everett III proposed a radical idea:
> The wave function never collapses.
Instead:

All outcomes happen simultaneously;

The universe branches into multiple realities, one for each possibility.

â¡ï¸ Each time a measurement occurs, the observer â€œsplitsâ€ along with the universe.

This interpretation eliminates collapse â€” but at the cost of admitting an infinity of parallel universes.





1.7.2 ğŸ§² Quantum Entanglement
The phenomenon of entanglement occurs when two quantum particles share a common state, even if separated by great distances.

Measuring one particle instantly affects the other, no matter how far apart they are.


Einstein rejected this idea, calling it
â€œspooky action at a distance.â€




1.7.3 ğŸ§ª Tests and Evidence
The theory was put to the test:

In 1964, John Bell formulated a theorem with testable inequalities:
â¡ï¸ If quantum mechanics is correct, certain correlations violate classical laws.
In 1982, Alain Aspect conducted experiments that confirmed quantum predictions â€” violating Bellâ€™s inequalities.

ğŸ“Œ Result: entanglement is real, and cannot be explained by local hidden-variable theories.

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§¬ 100 Years of Quantum Mechanics (1925â€“2025)
section: 1.8 ğŸ§© What Are Local Hidden Variables?
text:
1.8 ğŸ§© What Are Local Hidden Variables?
The hidden variables hypothesis proposes that quantum mechanics is not a complete theory, but rather a statistical description of deeper phenomena. The idea is that there exist hidden values â€” which determine the results of measurements, even if we donâ€™t know them.


1.8.1 ğŸ“ What Does â€œLocalâ€ Mean?
Locality implies that nothing can influence something at a distance faster than light â€” a requirement of Einsteinâ€™s relativity.

If two particles are separated by large distances, a measurement on one cannot instantaneously affect the other.




1.8.2 ğŸ§  The EPR Paradox (1935)
Einstein, Podolsky, and Rosen argued:

Quantum mechanics allows correlations between separated particles â€” entanglement;

But this violates locality, unless hidden variables exist to explain the phenomenon;

Therefore, quantum theory would be incomplete.




1.8.3 ğŸ“ Bellâ€™s Theorem (1964)
John Bell showed that:

If local hidden variables exist, certain mathematical inequalities must be respected;

Quantum mechanics predicts the violation of these inequalities.




1.8.4 ğŸ§ª Experiments

In 1982, Alain Aspect confirmed that Bellâ€™s inequalities are violated;

More recent experiments have closed technical loopholes;

Result: the universe does not obey local hidden variables.




1.8.5 ğŸ“Œ Conclusion
Quantum mechanics is:

Non-local (entangled particles share information beyond classical spacetime);

Indeterministic (results are not determined by â€œhidden propertiesâ€);

A theory fundamentally different from Einsteinâ€™s classical view.


Quantum reality is not defined until it is measured, and cannot be explained by local hidden mechanisms.




1.8.6 ğŸ” Modern Applications
Entanglement has ceased to be just a philosophical paradox.
Today, it is the foundation of emerging quantum technologies:

Quantum cryptography: secure communication using entangled pairs;

Quantum computing: simultaneous manipulation of states using interconnected qubits;

Quantum teleportation: transmission of quantum states at a distance.


ğŸŒ Entanglement connects not only particles, but also concepts of information, reality, and technology.

text:
1.10 ğŸŒ«ï¸ Quantum Decoherence
Decoherence is the process by which a quantum system loses its quantum properties â€” such as superposition and entanglement â€” when it interacts with the environment.


1.10.1 ğŸ§  Intuition
A qubit in superposition: \[
|\Psi\rangle = \alpha|0\rangle + \beta|1\rangle
\]
When it comes into contact with the environment (light, heat, noiseâ€¦), this superposition breaks down, and the system begins to behave as if it were in a single classical state.



1.10.2 ğŸ“‰ What Causes Decoherence?

Photons, vibrations, temperature;

Any exchange of information with the environment;

Even without direct measurement, the environment already interferes.

ğŸ” Decoherence connects the quantum world to the classical world â€” explaining why an electron can be in two places at once, but a cat cannot.

text:
1.11 Part 6 â€” One Hundred Years of Quantum Mechanics




Illustration â€” One Hundred Years of Quantum Mechanics




1.11.1 ğŸ‰ Technological Achievements
Quantum Mechanics, despite its counterintuitive concepts, is one of the most successful theories in the history of science. Its impact goes far beyond theoretical physics:

Lasers: based on stimulated quantum transitions between energy levels;

GPS: requires relativistic and quantum corrections to function accurately;

Electronic chips: work thanks to the quantum mechanics of semiconductors;

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI): uses spin and energy transitions to generate images of the body;

LEDs, solar panels, quantum sensors, atomic clocksâ€¦

ğŸ”¬ The theory of Quantum Electrodynamics (QED), formulated by Feynman, Schwinger, and Tomonaga, is the most precise in history:
> Predictions agree with experiments up to the 12th decimal place.



1.11.2 ğŸ§  Open Mysteries
Even with so many successes, quantum mechanics still defies our intuition. Major questions remain:

ğŸŒ€ What causes the collapse of the wave function?
The act of observation? Decoherence? Something deeper?
ğŸŒŒ How to unify gravity with quantum mechanics?
General Relativity and Quantum Mechanics are the two great pillars of modern physics â€” but they still do not coexist peacefully.


The search for a Quantum Theory of Gravity, such as loop quantum gravity or String Theory, is one of the greatest challenges of the century.




1.11.3 ğŸ”® The Future of Quantum Physics
We are entering the so-called Second Quantum Revolution, where we use quantum effects not just to understand, but to control and build technologies:

Quantum computers with hundreds or thousands of qubits;

Simulation of complex molecules, accelerating the discovery of new medicines;

Unbreakable quantum cryptography, based on entanglement and Bellâ€™s theorem;

Ultraprecise quantum sensors, with applications in geology, medicine, navigation, and space exploration.


Quantum physics is no longer â€œjust theoryâ€: it is shaping the future of technology and human knowledge.

title: ğŸ“˜ ğŸ§¬ 100 Years of Quantum Mechanics (1925â€“2025)
text:
1.12 ğŸ”š Conclusion
Quantum Mechanics is not just a theory about the very small â€” about atoms, particles, and laboratory experiments.
It is, in fact, a new way of seeing the world.

Over the last century, it has opened windows to realities that defy common sense:

An electron can be in several places at once;

Measuring something changes what is being measured;

Distant particles can be entangled, acting as if they were one;

And yet, everything works with almost absolute precision.



ğŸ”¬ Quantum Mechanics is at once mathematically rigorous and philosophically unsettling.

It revealed that there are limits to what we can know, and that nature, at its most fundamental level, is not made of certainties, but of probabilities, amplitudes, and subtle interactions.

More than that: it has become an essential tool for human progress.
It is present in lasers, computers, satellites, and even in the keyboards and screens through which you are reading this text.


â€œThe true mystery of the world is not the invisible.
It is the visible that seems so strange when looked at closely.â€

ğŸ”­ One hundred years later, Quantum Mechanics continues to teach us to see the familiar with new eyes â€” and to understand that, deep down, reality is stranger, more beautiful, and deeper than we ever imagined.





Visual synthesis of quantum mechanics


The wave, the atom, the photon, and the curvature of spacetime â€”
symbolic representations of a century of quantum discoveries that transformed our view of the universe.

1.1 Aesthetics in Pure Mathematics
In pure mathematics, the pursuit is not utilitarian, but rather conceptual, structural, abstract. The mathematician asks: is this coherent? profound? inevitable? beautiful?
Beauty, in this context, manifests in several ways: - Unexpected simplicity - Elegant generality - Surprising connections - Inevitable proofs
